It means that if the slope is zero the curve must be horizontal, since it neither rises nor falls, and this is the case at a turning point, either maximum or minimum. Hence turning points occur at points where $y$ is indicated by zero ordinates of the slope curve.

Again, a positive ordinate of the derived curve implies a positive slope of the primitive, and this indicates that in the neighbourhood considered the primitive increases with increase of abscissa. A large ordinate of the slope curve indicates rapid change of the primitive with regard to the abscissa.
